message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, which includes proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. Among the options, Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Acute glomerulonephritis can cause proteinuria and edema, but it is more common in adults. Congestive heart failure and protein-losing enteropathy also cause edema, but they generally do not cause significant proteinuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab findings suggest nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. Among the options, minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Acute glomerulonephritis can cause nephrotic syndrome in adults, but it is less common in children. Congestive heart failure and protein-losing enteropathy do not typically present with proteinuria and fatty casts.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of facial swelling progressing to total body swelling, along with proteinuria and fatty casts, suggest the most likely cause is minimal change disease, which is a condition where the glomeruli in the kidneys become abnormally permeable to proteins. Acute glomerulonephritis would present with hematuria and red cell casts. Congestive heart failure would be unlikely in a 2-year-old without other risk factors. Protein-losing enteropathy would present with chronic diarrhea and malnutrition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of nephrotic syndrome, such as proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. Among the options, minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Acute glomerulonephritis shows hematuria, red blood cell casts, and elevated blood pressure, which the patient does not have. Congestive heart failure shows elevated jugular venous pressure and pulmonary edema, which the patient does not have. Protein-losing enteropathy usually manifests with diarrhea, weight loss, and peripheral edema, which the patient does not have.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of facial swelling, total body swelling, abdominal pain, and proteinuria suggest nephrotic syndrome. Among the options, minimal change disease is the most likely cause in a 2-year-old boy. Acute glomerulonephritis is more common in older children, while congestive heart failure and protein-losing enteropathy do not typically present with the same constellation of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest nephrotic syndrome, with significant protein loss through urine and low serum albumin. Among the options, only Minimal change disease is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Acute glomerulonephritis will cause hematuria and proteinuria, which is not seen in this patient. Congestive heart failure will cause heart-related symptoms, which is also not seen in this patient. Protein-losing enteropathy is a possibility but is less likely given the presence of edema.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. Among the options, minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Acute glomerulonephritis would have hematuria and elevated blood pressure. Congestive heart failure would have respiratory distress and decreased cardiac output. Protein-losing enteropathy would have diarrhea and malabsorption.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including facial and body swelling, proteinuria, and hypoalbuminemia suggest that the most likely etiology is Minimal change disease. Acute glomerulonephritis would have hematuria and red blood cell casts. Congestive heart failure would have different vital sign readings and symptoms. Protein-losing enteropathy would have a different clinical picture with regards to edema and abdominal findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. The presence of fatty casts indicates that lipid material is being excreted in the urine. Among the options, only Minimal change disease can cause this kind of symptoms. Acute glomerulonephritis will cause hematuria and proteinuria with red cell casts. Congestive heart failure will cause edema with elevated jugular venous pressure. Protein-losing enteropathy will cause edema with diarrhea and malabsorption.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of progressive swelling, proteinuria, and fatty casts suggest nephrotic syndrome. Among the options, minimal change disease is the most likely cause of nephrotic syndrome in a 2-year-old child with no other significant medical history. Acute glomerulonephritis is more common in older children and adults and is often associated with recent infections. Congestive heart failure is unlikely in this young child with normal vital signs and no known cardiac history. Protein-losing enteropathy is a possibility but less likely than minimal change disease in this patient population.
